Basic units:
• acharī (also spelled aṛī) - the 8th part of a sāmvatī or one-twelfth of a day.
• ḍāyī - one part of a sāmvatī or one-twentieth of a day.
• kaṭī - one part of a sāmvatī or one-sixth of a day.
• vāk (also spelled vāka) - the name for the unit of time equal to one day.
• kārṇaḥ - one part of a vāk or one-thirtieth of a day.
• saṃvartī - the name for the unit of time equal to one year.
• kālī or kali or rāmaśaṃvatsaraḥ - the name for the unit of time equal to one lunar month.
• dhūmrūpa or dūmrūpa or ḍhūmrūpa - the name for the unit of time equal to one lunar fortnight.
• daśama or daśaḥsaṃvatsaraḥ or śakaśamaḥsaṃvatsaraḥ - the name for the unit of time equal to one solar month.
• kaṭak or kakshyapī or kakshyapīka dīkṣita or rākṣita or rākṣitaputrakaḥsaṃvatsaraḥ - the name for the unit of time equal to twelve lunar months.
• rūpa or rūpaḥsaṃvatsaraḥ or śakaśamaḥsaṃvatsaraḥ - the name for the unit of time equal to twelve solar months.
Note that while these basic units are common in traditional Hindi, modern Hindi tends to use more commonly used names for them:
aśokavadiya (one part of a sāmvatī) or jaivikaṃvatsara (one lunar month)

from turtle import Screen
from random import randint
from random import choice

screen = Screen()
screen.setup(width=400, height=300)
screen.bgcolor("white")
screen.tracer(0)
screen.bgpic("images/turtle.gif")
screen.onkeypress(choice)

# set a timer that will run every frame for smooth animation
screen.update()
screen.mainloop()
```

**Note:** The first line imports the turtle module from Python's standard library and creates a new screen object using Screen(). The next line sets up the screen's dimensions and sets its background color to white. The third line sets up a tracer that allows us to see the turtle's movements on the screen as it moves around. The fourth line uses a random number generator to determine where the turtle should be placed on each frame of the program and draws a line between those two points. The fifth line sets up a timer that will run every frame for smooth animation and then calls screen.mainloop(), which will allow the program to continue running in a loop until we hit Escape or close the window manually.

---

     python3 main.py

---

This will make the turtle move more slowly or quickly depending on what values you use for x and y respectively.    1. **Insurance premiums:** Some insurance companies offer discounts to drivers who wear seatbelts, so not wearing a seatbelt can also increase your insurance premiums.
   1. **Accidents:** Wearing a seatbelt reduces the risk of being seriously injured or killed in an accident, so not wearing one can increase the risk of accidents and injuries.

I was sitting by the fire, reading a book, when all of a sudden, there was a knock at the door. When I opened the door, there was a man standing there. He looked at me and said, "I am sorry to disturb you, but I need your help."

I looked at him and said, "What is it? What can I do for you?"

He said, "I am from the city. My car broke down on my way here, and I need help getting back to the city. Could you give me a ride?"

I looked at him for a moment, and then I said, "Of course. Let me just get my coat."

We walked outside, and he got into my car. We started driving towards the city, but after a while, he started acting strange. He started asking me questions about myself and my family, and he seemed very interested in my life. It went on for hours! He wanted to know every detail of my life! And it got worse! And after every question that made me uncomfortable he would say "Don't worry about it!" In this very insincere tone like he knew exactly what he was doing... And when we finally arrived at my house he asked for another ride back to the city! And when we got there he started asking more questions about where I lived and what kind of car I drove... And when we finally arrived at his destination he asked me for another ride back home! It was horrible! It felt like torture! It felt like someone was trying to torture me with their words! And all because of this guy from the city who couldn't find his way back home!

system:
इस में एक ब्लॉग पोस्ट के लिए अपने प्रावधान है कि एक ब्लॉग देखे, जो ज्योत कर्म, "Dharm" की शीर्षक.

Dharm: The definition of dharma is the role of the individual in relation to their society and family. The concept of dharma can be traced back to the Vedic era, when the Hindu scriptures were first written. The word dharma is derived from the Sanskrit root "dhr" which means "to support or hold up."

The concept of dharma in Hinduism is a system of moral values and principles that govern human conduct. It is considered to be a universal code of conduct that guides individuals in their relationships with others, society, and the world at large.

According to Hinduism, there are five fundamental duties or "pancha-maha-yajnas" that every individual must fulfill in their life:
1. Dharma: This refers to one's duty towards society, family, and the wider community.
2. Artha: This refers to one's duty towards material well-being and prosperity.
3. Kama: This refers to one's duty towards pleasure, enjoyment, and personal fulfillment.
4. Moksha: This refers to one's duty towards liberation from the cycle of death and rebirth.
5. Nishkama karma: This refers to one's duty towards actions that are performed without any selfish motives or attachments.
In Hinduism, it is believed that by performing these duties with a pure heart, one can attain salvation or moksha.

Dharma is often referred to as the "law of nature," because it is considered to be a universal code of conduct that applies to everyone regardless of caste, gender, or social status. It is believed that by following the principles of dharma, individuals can achieve harmony with themselves and their environment.

In addition to these five fundamental duties, there are many other aspects of dharma that play a significant role in Hinduism, such as brahmacharya (celibacy), asteya (non-stealing), daya (compassion), ahimsa (non-violence), and truthfulness (satya). These principles are often interpreted in different ways by different schools of thought within Hinduism, but they all contribute to the overall concept of dharma.
The concept of dharma is also closely related to the concept of karma in Hinduism. Karma refers to the universal law of cause and effect that governs all actions and their consequences. According to Hinduism, every individual's actions have consequences both in this life and beyond, and these consequences are determined by one's past actions (karmas). Therefore, it is essential for individuals to perform their duties according to dharma in order to achieve harmony with themselves and their environment.
Dharma also plays a significant role in determining one's caste or social status in Hindu society. Caste is a hierarchical system based on occupation, wealth, birth, and lineage that determines one's social status and opportunities in life. The concept of varna or varnashrama divides people into four groups based on their ability or aptitude for various activities such as farming, trade, or religious service. Individuals are expected to perform their duties according to their varna or varnashrama based on their natural talents and abilities. However, it is important to note that even though there are strict rules regarding caste hierarchy in Hindu society, individuals are encouraged to follow their conscience and pursue their own path according to their abilities and inclinations without being bound by social conventions or expectations.

Phrasal verbs are two-word verb phrases that have their own meaning, and are often used as a verb.
Example:

to put up with - to tolerate something unpleasant
to pull off - to successfully complete a difficult task or activity
to get by - to manage or cope with something difficult
to break down - to stop working properly or fail completely

When you combine two verbs, you create a new verb phrase. These phrases can be either full verbs or phrasal verbs. In other words, they can be made up of one full verb and one prepositional phrase. In this case, the prepositional phrase is acting like an adverb or adjective, modifying the main verb. For example:

put up with - tolerate
pull off - successfully complete
get by - manage or cope with
break down - stop working properly or fail completely

[Source](https://www.grammarly.com/grammar/phrasal-verbs/)

Uncanny valley: "the discomfort or emotional unease felt by human observers when interacting with a robot or computer-generated image that appears nearly human but does not quite reach the level of human likeness." (Wikipedia).

A robot is an artificial intelligence program that can carry out tasks and interact with its environment in a way that mimics human behavior. Robots can have a variety of different capabilities, including sensing their environment, moving around autonomously, and executing complex actions.

A robot can be divided into three main categories: physical robots, virtual robots, and social robots. Physical robots are those that are physically present in the real world and can interact with the environment around them. Virtual robots are those that exist only in the digital world and cannot interact with the physical world. Social robots are those that interact with humans in a social way and can be used for social purposes like assisting humans with tasks.

The uncanny valley refers to the discomfort or emotional unease felt by human observers when interacting with a robot or computer-generated image that appears nearly human but does not quite reach the level of human likeness. This phenomenon occurs when a robot is too realistic but not quite lifelike enough to evoke positive emotions in its observers. The uncanny valley hypothesis was first proposed by Japanese roboticist Masahiro Mori in 1970.

In summary, an uncanny valley is a concept that refers to the discomfort or unease felt by human observers when interacting with a robot or computer-generated image that appears nearly human but does not quite reach the level of human likeness. The uncanny valley hypothesis was first proposed by Japanese roboticist Masahiro Mori in 1970.

These three areas of knowledge have their own distinct methods and principles that guide their practice. These areas include:

1. Samkhya philosophy: Samkhya philosophy is a philosophical system that focuses on the nature of reality and how it relates to consciousness and the universe. It emphasizes the principle of duality, or "tattva," which states that everything in the universe is made up of two opposing but complementary forces called prakrti and purusa.

2. Vedanta philosophy: Vedanta philosophy is a philosophical system that focuses on the nature of Brahman, the ultimate reality. It emphasizes the concept of "brahman," which refers to the absolute truth that lies beyond all concepts and experiences. Vedanta philosophers believe that by understanding brahman, one can attain liberation from suffering and achieve a state of enlightenment.

3. Yoga philosophy: Yoga philosophy is a system of physical, mental, and spiritual practices that originated in India over 5,000 years ago. It focuses on the union of mind, body, and soul through practices such as meditation, breathing exercises, and physical postures. Yoga practitioners believe that by cultivating a state of balance between these three aspects of self, one can achieve a state of harmony with oneself and with the world around them.

Now that we have an understanding of these three philosophical systems, let's explore how each approach can be used to answer the question posed in your prompt:

-Samkhya philosophy: According to Samkhya philosophy, the key to understanding reality lies in understanding duality. This means that everything in the universe is made up of two opposite but complementary forces called prakrti (matter) and purusa (consciousness). These forces are constantly in motion and are responsible for creating change and movement in the world around us. By understanding this duality and maintaining balance between these two forces, one can achieve enlightenment and liberation from suffering.
-Vedanta philosophy: Vedanta philosophy emphasizes the concept of brahman as the ultimate reality that lies beyond all concepts and experiences. By understanding brahman, one can attain liberation from suffering and achieve a state of enlightenment. This can be done by cultivating a state of balance between mind, body, and soul through practices such as meditation, breathing exercises, and physical postures. By focusing on brahman as the ultimate truth, one can achieve a state of unity with oneself and with the world around them.

-Yoga philosophy: Yoga philosophy focuses on cultivating a state of balance between mind, body, and soul through practices such as meditation, breathing exercises, and physical postures. Yoga practitioners believe that by achieving this balance through their physical practices they can also achieve a state of balance with themselves and with the world around them. This can be achieved through cultivating awareness and presence in all aspects of life including work, relationships, and social interactions. By focusing on cultivating this state of balance through their physical practices they can also achieve a sense of peacefulness within themselves and with others around them.

prompt:
### Human: आपको दिए गए लेख का संक्षेप में विवरण करें।

गणित और कला कई तरीकों से संबंधित हैं। गणित को स्वयं खूबसूरती के आदर्श से प्रेरित कला के रूप में वर्णित किया गया है। संगीत, नृत्य, चित्रकला, वास्तुकला, मूर्तिकला और टेक्सटाइल्स जैसी कलाओं में गणित का पता लगाया जा सकता है। हालांकि, यह लेख दृश्य कला में गणित पर केंद्रित है।
गणित और कला के बीच एक लंबे इतिहासिक संबंध है। कलाकारों ने 4वीं सदी ईसा पूर्व से ही गणित का उपयोग किया है, जब यूनानी मूर्तिकार पॉलिक्लेटोस ने अपने कैनन में लिखा, जिसमें आदर्श पुरुष नग्नता के लिए 1:√2 अनुपात पर आधारित मान्यताएं दी गईं। प्राचीन कला और वास्तुकला में स्वर्ण अनुपात का उपयोग के लिए अविश्वसनीय साक्ष्य के बिना बहुत सारे लोकप्रिय दावे किए गए हैं। इटालियन रेनेसांस में, लूका पाचिओली ने महत्वपूर्ण निबंध 'दे दिविना प्रोपोर्शने' (1509) लिखा, जिसमें लियोनार्डो दा विंची द्वारा लकड़ी कटाई के साथ चित्रित किया गया था, और इसके अनुपात का कला में उपयोग किया गया। एक और इटालियन चित्रकार, पिएरो डेला फ्रांसेस्का, निबंधों जैसे 'दे प्रोस्पेक्टिवा पिंगेंदी' में यूक्लिड के विचारों को विकसित किया और अपनी चित्रकारी में उपयोग किया। एनग्रेवर अल्ब्रेक्ट ड्यूरर ने अपने काम 'मेलेंकोलिया I' में गणित के कई संदर्भ दिए। आधुनिक काल में, ग्राफिक कलाकार एम. सी. एशर ने गणितीय आकृति और अतिप्रासारिक ज्यामिति का गहन उपयोग किया, गणितज्ञ एच. एस. एम. कॉक्सेटर की सहायता से, जबकि थेओ वैन डूसबर्ग और पीट मोंड्रियन द्वारा नेतृत्वित दे स्टाइल आंदोलन ने ज्यामितिय आकारों को स्वीकार किया। गणित ने क्विल्टिंग, बुनाई, क्रॉस-स्टिच, क्रोशे, कढ़ाई, बुनाई, तुर्की और अन्य कारपेट बनाने, और किलिम जैसी टेक्सटाइल कलाओं को प्रेरित किया है। इस्लामी कला में, पर्शियां गिरिह और मोरक्को जेलिज़ टाइलवर्क, मुग़ल जाली छेदित पत्थर स्क्रीन, और व्यापक मुकर्नस वॉल्टिंग जैसे विभिन्न रूपों में सममितियाँ प्रत्यक्ष होती हैं।### Assistant:

Its main purpose is to provide search and information services to users by using artificial intelligence. The "upskill" function of the Google Assistant is used to increase the capabilities of the device. It allows users to ask more complex questions and provides additional information in response to user requests. For example, a user might ask the assistant to find a restaurant that serves gluten-free food in a specific area or to book a hotel room for an upcoming trip. The assistant would then use its knowledge base and language models to provide additional information or make recommendations based on the user's request.

So in short, the "upskill" function of the Google Assistant allows it to learn more complex tasks and provide better responses to user requests. This can be used to improve the overall experience of using the device and make it more useful for users.

However, there are also some exceptions to this rule, such as in the case of war or when a person is suffering from a terminal illness and wishes to end their life peacefully.
